paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Whether intratumoral delivery of an mRNA vaccine can create an interferon-rich inflammatory state that improves sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 immune checkpoint blockade.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse efficacy cohort (combination therapy)
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Pooled across repeat experiments to assess tumor control with intratumoral mRNA vaccine combined with anti-PD-L1 treatment.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse control cohort (vaccine only, ICI only, vehicle)
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Matched control conditions (vaccine-only, ICI-only and vehicle) pooled across experiments to contextualize combination-therapy effects.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human retrospective metastatic cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Retrospective cohort of metastatic patients treated with immune checkpoint inhibitors, stratified by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human vaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subset of the retrospective metastatic cohort with prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination, compared for outcomes under ICI treatment.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human unvaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subset of the retrospective metastatic cohort without prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination, used as the comparator for vaccinated patients.

major_limitations: Human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; confounding likely.
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit causal inference.
Mouse model effects may not translate one-to-one to human tumors.
Mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems only.
